docs.lead_paragraph: People are rightly concerned about health care costs, experts say, but some fears are off base.

headline.main: Policy Experts Call Fear of Medical Rationing Unfounded
headline.print_headline: Policy Experts Call Fear of Medical Rationing Unfounded

docs.snippet: People are rightly concerned about health care costs, experts say, but some fears are off base.

docs.lead_paragraph: How good for hospitals was the deal they made with the Obama administration to support the effort at a health care overhaul? Fairly good, according to a run through the numbers by one hospital association. When the White House and hospital officials announced in July that the industry would agree to $155 billion in medical cost savings over 10 years, some experts wondered what the hospitals expected in return. Now a cost-benefit breakdown posted on the Web site of the Tennessee Hospital Association fills in more of the answer.
docs.abstract: Deal hospitals made with Obama administration to support health care overhaul discussed; White House and hospital officials announced in July that industry would agree to $155 billion in medical cost savings over 10 years; Web site of Tennessee Hospital Assn web site breakdown estimates that industry will receive additional $171 billion over 10 years as result of expansion of health insurance, $16 billion more than would be sacrificed (M)
docs.snippet: How good for hospitals was the deal they made with the Obama administration to support the effort at a health care overhaul? Fairly good, according to a run through the numbers by one hospital association.      When the White House and hospital...

docs.lead_paragraph: In 2006, annual health spending in this country was less than $800 per individual for half the population. But spending varies widely, and the high-cost people include the elderly, the obese and people who identify themselves as unhealthy. Median spending for those groups was $2,300 in 2006, and 10 percent of such cases exceeded $15,000. Although those groups make up only about one-third of the United States population, as shown below they account for almost 60 percent of health care spending.

headline.main: The Few Who Cost the Most

docs.abstract: Article discusses 2006 annual health spending in US that cost less than $800 per individual for half of population; finds that spending varies widely and that high-cost people include elderly, obese and people who identify themselves as unhealthy; median spending for those groups was $2,300 in 2006; 10 percent of such cases exceeded $15,000; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the campaign for the hearts and minds of older Americans -- the cohort most nervous about a health care overhaul -- Michael Steele, chairman of the Republican National Committee, was on a tour for journalists Monday promoting a Seniors' Health Care Bill of Rights. It says Republicans will, among other things, protect Medicare. And it accuses Democrats of ''promoting a government-run health care experiment that will cut over $500 billion from Medicare.''
docs.abstract: Republican National Committee's new chairman Michael Steele is promoting Seniors' Health Care Bill of Rights, which says that Republicans will protect Medicare; bill accuses Democrats of promoting government-run health care experiment that will cut over $500 billion from Medicare (M)
docs.snippet: In the campaign for the hearts and minds of older Americans -- the cohort most nervous about a health care overhaul -- Michael Steele, chairman of the Republican National Committee, was on a tour for journalists Monday promoting a Seniors' Health...

docs.lead_paragraph: Update | 9:02 p.m. An earlier version of this article repeated an erroneous figure in the Tennessee Hospital Association's analysis. That error has been corrected in this article, but is still incorrect on the hospital association's document. The $171 billion number covers all 10 years. It is not an annual figure for 10 years.

headline.main: Hospitals See Profits in White House Deal

docs.abstract: A hospital industry analysis of its cost-cutting deal with the Obama administration forecasts a profitable outcome for hospitals.
docs.snippet: A hospital industry analysis of its cost-cutting deal with the Obama administration forecasts a profitable outcome for hospitals.

docs.lead_paragraph: An alliance of liberal advocacy groups is stepping up pressure on Democratic senators to declare their support for a government-backed health insurance plan, the so-called public option.

headline.main: Group Aims at 8 Senators for 'Public Option'

docs.abstract: An alliance of liberal groups is aiming money at eight senators it hopes will support a public insurance option.
docs.snippet: An alliance of liberal groups is aiming money at eight senators it hopes will support a public insurance option.

docs.lead_paragraph: Matthew Reeve was 15 and had just finished coursework at his London school when his phone rang at 6 a.m. It's a vivid memory because it was the moment he learned his father, the movie star Christopher Reeve, had been seriously injured in an equestrian accident.

headline.main: Christopher Reeve's Son Tackles the Marathon

docs.abstract: Matthew Reeve, son of actor Christopher Reeve, talks about his plans to run the New York City Marathon to raise money for spinal cord injury research.
docs.snippet: Matthew Reeve, son of actor Christopher Reeve, talks about his plans to run the New York City Marathon to raise money for spinal cord injury research.

docs.lead_paragraph: Much of the health care debate has focused on medical care, but today the City Room blog highlights how job losses can affect dental health.
docs.abstract: Much of the health care debate has focused on medical care, but job losses also can affect dental health.
docs.snippet: Much of the health care debate has focused on medical care, but job losses also can affect dental health.

docs.lead_paragraph: From our friends at the Economix blog, an entry from Nancy Folbre, an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.:

headline.main: Buying Into the Health of the Planet

docs.abstract: An economist draws parallels between the climate-change debate and the health-care debate in Washington, and discusses a cap-and-dividend proposal.
docs.snippet: An economist draws parallels between the climate-change debate and the health-care debate in Washington, and discusses a cap-and-dividend proposal.

docs.lead_paragraph: Washington watchers and national security buffs will spend the day poring through a long-withheld and highly anticipated 2004 inspector general's report on abuses that took place at the Central Intelligence Agency's secret prisons.
docs.abstract: A report by the inspector general of the C.I.A. from 2004 is about to be released.
docs.snippet: A report by the inspector general of the C.I.A. from 2004 is about to be released.
